case_vignette: a 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain that began suddenly 2 weeks ago after getting up from her chair. she has hypertension, chronic bilateral knee pain, and a history of breast cancer 15 years ago that was treated with lumpectomy. her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. medications include hydrochlorothiazide and acetaminophen. she appears well. her vital signs are within normal limits. physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the lower spine. both knees are enlarged and swollen. neurologic examination shows sensorineural hearing impairment of the left ear. her gamma-glutamyl transferase (ggt) is 30 u/l (n: 0–30 u/l), alkaline phosphatase (alp) is 310 u/l, and serum calcium is 10.2 mg/dl. a spinal x-ray shows a fracture in the l4 vertebra.
question: which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Rheumatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing lower back pain that started suddenly two weeks ago after I got up from my chair.
Do you feel the pain radiating to your legs or is it confined to the lower back?
The pain is confined to my lower back.
Have you had any recent accidents or injuries that could have affected your lower back?
No, I haven't had any recent accidents or injuries.
Do you have any other symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or changes in bowel or bladder function?
No, I do not have any of those symptoms.
Is the pain constant throughout the day or does it feel worse at a particular time, like in the morning or after prolonged sitting?
The pain began suddenly and there's no specific mention of it worsening at certain times of the day or after activities like sitting.
Does the pain improve with movement or exercise, or does it worsen?
The description does not specify how movement or exercise affects the pain.
Have you experienced similar episodes of lower back pain in the past, or is this the first occurrence?
This is the first occurrence of such lower back pain.
Do you have a history of autoimmune diseases or inflammatory conditions in your family?
Yes, my mother has rheumatoid arthritis.
Final Diagnosis: Ankylosing Spondylitis

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports suffering from lower back pain that initiated abruptly two weeks ago after arising from a chair. There is no mention of how movement or exercise impacts the pain. This is the patient's first experience of such lower back pain. The patient’s mother has a medical history of rheumatoid arthritis.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Acute mechanical back pain (musculoskeletal low back pain).
